title: 108_s1582
content: The Act may be cited as the "Valles Caldera Preservation Act of 2004" and includes amendments to the Valles Caldera Preservation Act. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act of 2004 includes amendments regarding the acquisition of outstanding mineral interests by the Secretary with available funds. If negotiations are unsuccessful, the Secretary can acquire the interests through a declaration of taking. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act of 2004 allows the Secretary to acquire outstanding mineral interests if negotiations fail. The Secretary can use available funds for acquisition, and any difference in compensation will be paid from a permanent judgment appropriation. The Trust is responsible for determining obligations and expenditures in accordance with applicable laws. The Trust is responsible for determining obligations and expenditures for Government corporations. The Board of Trustees, executive director, and one additional employee may solicit donations. Proceeds from claims or settlements after October 27, 1999, can be used for activities on the Baca Ranch or Preserve. The Board of Trustees is responsible for overseeing Government corporations and can solicit donations. Proceeds from claims or settlements after October 27, 1999, can be used for activities on the Baca Ranch or Preserve. Section 107(e) of the Valles Caldera Preservation Act is amended to specify the selection and compensation of trustees, with the chair potentially receiving compensation not exceeding a certain rate. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act amends Section 107(e) to outline the selection and compensation of trustees, limiting the chair's compensation to 25% of the annual rate of pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act outlines resource management in Section 4. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act is amended to include property disposal limitations and exclusions for real property. Additionally, amendments are made to law enforcement and fire management provisions. Amendments are made to the Valles Caldera Preservation Act regarding law enforcement and fire management. The Secretary is required to develop a plan for fire preparedness, suppression, and emergency rehabilitation services in consultation with the Trust. The Secretary, in consultation with the Trust, must develop a plan for fire preparedness, suppression, and emergency rehabilitation services on the Preserve. The plan should align with the management program and be carried out under a cooperative agreement. Reimbursable services may also be provided for presuppression efforts. The Secretary may provide presuppression and nonemergency rehabilitation and restoration services for the Trust on a reimbursable basis under a cooperative agreement. The Senate passed the document on September 15, 2004, with Emily J. Reynolds as the Secretary.
